greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the largest integer m such that 2^m divides (2*n)^n, i.e., the exponent of 2 in (2*n)^n.
comment: n times one more than the trailing 0's in the binary representation of n. - _Ralf Stephan_, Aug 22 2013
link: Vincenzo Librandi, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Index entries for sequences related to binary expansion of n
formula: Mobius transform of A162728, where x/(1-x)^2 = Sum_{n>=1} A162728(n)*x^n/(1+x^n). - _Paul D. Hanna_, Jul 12 2009
a((2*n-1)*2^p) = (2*n-1)*(p+1)*2^p, p >= 0. Observe that a(2^p) = A001787(p+1). - _Johannes W. Meijer_, Feb 08 2013
maple: nmax:=63: for p from 0 to ceil(simplify(log[2](nmax))) do for n from 1 to ceil(nmax/(p+2)) do a((2*n-1)*2^p) := (2*n-1)*(p+1)*2^p od: od: seq(a(n), n=1..nmax); # _Johannes W. Meijer_, Feb 08 2013
results.author: _Ralf Stephan_ and _Labos Elemer_, Jan 18 2004
